1.  Waveguides

[A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1)! Waveguides can indeed pose some limitations in photonic computing [A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). One of the main challenges is the **low refractive index contrast** between the core and cladding materials, which can lead to **inefficient coupling** of light into the waveguide [A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). This can be particularly problematic when integrating single photon sources, such as quantum dots, into the circuits [A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1).

Additionally, waveguides can suffer from **propagation losses** and **phase instability**, which can degrade the performance of photonic devices [A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). These issues can limit the scalability and efficiency of photonic quantum computing systems [A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1).

Researchers are actively exploring new materials and fabrication techniques to overcome these challenges [A](https://www.kth.se/polopoly_fs/1.1292569.1699124959!/1-s2.0-S0030399223011696-main.pdf?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). For example, hybrid plasmonic waveguides combine photonic and plasmonic components to achieve better confinement and lower losses [B](https://pubs.aip.org/tu/npe/article/7/4/045001/3308256/Past-present-and-future-of-hybrid-plasmonic?copilot_analytics_%3D%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). Other approaches include using microspheres to enhance light coupling efficiency [C](https://www.mdpi.com/2304-6732/11/4/343?copilot_analytics_metadata=eyJldmVudEluZm9fY2xpY2tTb3VyY2UiOiJjaXRhdGlvbkxpbmsiLCJldmVudEluZm9fY2xpY2tEZXN0aW5hdGlvbiI6Imh0dHBzOlwvXC93d3cubWRwaS5jb21cLzIzMDQtNjczMlwvMTFcLzRcLzM0MyIsImV2ZW50SW5mb19tZXNzYWdlSWQiOiIzYzZSNVkxekFqOVY5VXplcTNISEoiLCJldmVudEluZm9fY29udmVyc2F0aW9uSWQiOiJhYTVDNXFZY3laenlRNG55TDFRZ1QifQ%3D%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1).

2.  Coherence

[A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1)! Coherence in quantum devices is indeed influenced by several factors, including the distance photons travel through the device and the properties of the materials used [B](https://www.trailyn.com/exploring-the-role-of-coherence-in-quantum-computing/?copilot_analytics_%3D%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). 

**Distance**: As photons travel through a device, they can interact with the environment, leading to **decoherence** [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). The longer the distance, the more likely these interactions are to occur, which can disrupt the quantum state [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1).

**Material Properties**: The materials used in the device can also impact coherence [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). Factors such as **material purity**, **surface roughness**, and **optical losses** can all contribute to decoherence [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). High-quality materials with minimal imperfections are essential for maintaining coherence [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1).

Other factors that can affect coherence include **temperature**, **noise**, and **external electromagnetic fields** [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1). Researchers are continually working on methods to mitigate these effects and improve coherence times in quantum devices [A](https://quantumai.co/understanding-quantum-coherence-the-key-to-stable-qubits/?copilot_analytics_%3D&citationMarker=9F742443-6C92-4C44-BF58-8F5A7C53B6F1).
